para.p:
Let
= n 3
, and take
< p
4 3
. Some of the material we will present for general
n
when it doesn’t simplify our work to use
= n 3
.
The (defocusing) nonlinear Schrödinger equation is

Math.text: i * phi _ t + Delta * phi + (absolute-value@(phi)) ^ (p - 1) * phi = 0

para.p:
For a function
ψ
on
R n
, the orbit of the function under the symmetries of NLS is

We say that
ψ
is orbitally stable if initial data being near it implies that the solution of NLS is near it always.
We define
The ground state equation is

Math.text: (Delta * u - u) + (absolute-value@(u)) ^ (p - 1) * u = 0

para.p:
The ground state equation comes from the solution
=
⁢ ϕ
( x , t )
⁢
e
⁢ i t
u
( x )
of NLS. It is a fact that there is a positive bounded solution
R
of the ground state equation, which we call a ground state.

p.text:
The ground state
R
is orbitally stable: for any
> ϵ 0
there is a
>
⁢ δ
( ϵ )
0
such that if

Math.text: rho * open-interval@(phi _ 0, G _ R) less delta * epsilon
rho * open-interval@(phi * t, G _ R) less epsilon

para.p:
We define the energy functional
E
by

Math.text: E * delimited-[]@(phi) = (integral@((absolute-value@(nabla@(phi))) ^ 2) + (absolute-value@(phi)) ^ 2) - (2 / (p + 1)) * (absolute-value@(phi)) ^ (p + 1) * d * x

para.p:
so
⁢ E
[ ϕ ]
is a function of time but not of space.

It is a fact that for each
t
there are
=
x 0
⁢
x 0
( t )
and
= γ
⁢ γ
( t )
such that

Let
w = ϕ
( ⋅ +
x 0
, t )
e
⁢ i γ
- R
; so
=
∥
⁢ w
( t )
∥
H 1
⁢ ρ
(
⁢ ϕ
( t )
,
G R
)
.

Let
=
⁢ Δ E
-
⁢ E
[
ϕ 0
]
⁢ E
[ R ]
. We have

Math.text: Delta * E
E * delimited-[]@(R + w) - E * delimited-[]@(R)

para.p:
We shall express
⁢ E
[
+ R w
]
as a Taylor expansion about
R
. We compute the first variation as follows:

Math.tex:
\displaystyle d\mathscr{E}[R]w=\int
abla w
abla\overline{R}+
abla R
abla%
\overline{w}+w\overline{R}+R\overline{w}-|R|^{p-1}(w\overline{R}+R\overline{w}%
)=2\Re\int
abla w
abla R+wR-w|R|^{p-1}R=2\Re\int w(-\Delta R+R-|R|^{p-1}R)=0,
Math.text: d * E * delimited-[]@(R) * w = (integral@(nabla@(w) * nabla@(overline@(R))) + nabla@(R) * nabla@(overline@(w)) + w * overline@(R) + R * overline@(w)) - (absolute-value@(R)) ^ (p - 1) * (w * overline@(R) + R * overline@(w)) = (2 * real-part * integral@(nabla@(w) * nabla@(R)) + w * R) - w * (absolute-value@(R)) ^ (p - 1) * R = 2 * real-part * integral@(w * (((- Delta * R) + R) - (absolute-value@(R)) ^ (p - 1) * R)) = 0
d * E * delimited-[]@(R) * w
(integral@(nabla@(w) * nabla@(overline@(R))) + nabla@(R) * nabla@(overline@(w)) + w * overline@(R) + R * overline@(w)) - (absolute-value@(R)) ^ (p - 1) * (w * overline@(R) + R * overline@(w))
(2 * real-part * integral@(nabla@(w) * nabla@(R)) + w * R) - w * (absolute-value@(R)) ^ (p - 1) * R
2 * real-part * integral@(w * (((- Delta * R) + R) - (absolute-value@(R)) ^ (p - 1) * R))

para.p:
where we used the fact that
R
is real valued, integration by parts, and the fact that
R
is a solution of the ground state equation. So the first variation of
E
at
R
is
0
.

We now compute the second variation of
E
.

Math.text: d ^ 2 * E * delimited-[]@(R) * delimited-[]@(w) = ((2 * real-part * integral - w * Delta * overline@(w)) + (absolute-value@(w)) ^ 2) - ((p - 1) / 2) * R ^ (p - 1) * w ^ 2 - ((p - 1) / 2) * R ^ (p - 1) * (absolute-value@(w)) ^ 2 - R ^ (p - 1) * (absolute-value@(w)) ^ 2 = ((2 * real-part * integral - w * Delta * overline@(w)) + (absolute-value@(w)) ^ 2) - ((p - 1) / 2) * R ^ (p - 1) * w ^ 2 - ((p + 1) / 2) * R ^ (p - 1) * (absolute-value@(w)) ^ 2
d ^ 2 * E * delimited-[]@(R) * delimited-[]@(w)
((2 * real-part * integral - w * Delta * overline@(w)) + (absolute-value@(w)) ^ 2) - ((p - 1) / 2) * R ^ (p - 1) * w ^ 2 - ((p - 1) / 2) * R ^ (p - 1) * (absolute-value@(w)) ^ 2
- R ^ (p - 1) * (absolute-value@(w)) ^ 2
((2 * real-part * integral - w * Delta * overline@(w)) + (absolute-value@(w)) ^ 2) - ((p - 1) / 2) * R ^ (p - 1) * w ^ 2 - ((p + 1) / 2) * R ^ (p - 1) * (absolute-value@(w)) ^ 2

para.p:
Write
= w
+ u
⁢ i v
. Then we have

Math.text: d ^ 2 * E * delimited-[]@(R) * delimited-[]@(w) = ((2 * integral - u * Delta * u - v * Delta * v) + u ^ 2 + v ^ 2) - R ^ (p - 1) * (p * u ^ 2 + v ^ 2)
d ^ 2 * E * delimited-[]@(R) * delimited-[]@(w)
((2 * integral - u * Delta * u - v * Delta * v) + u ^ 2 + v ^ 2) - R ^ (p - 1) * (p * u ^ 2 + v ^ 2)

para.p: Define

Math.text: formulae@(L _ + = ((- Delta) + 1) - p * R ^ (p - 1), L _ - = ((- Delta) + 1) - R ^ (p - 1))

para.p: which gives

Math.text: (open-interval@(L _ + * u, u)) _ (L ^ 2) = ((integral - u * Delta * u) + u ^ 2) - p * u ^ 2 * R ^ (p - 1)

para.p: and

Math.text: (open-interval@(L _ - * v, v)) _ (L ^ 2) = ((integral - v * Delta * v) + v ^ 2) - v ^ 2 * R ^ (p - 1)

para.p: Thus

Math.text: d ^ 2 * E * delimited-[]@(R) * delimited-[]@(w) = 2 * (open-interval@(L _ + * u, u)) _ (L ^ 2) + 2 * (open-interval@(L _ - * v, v)) _ (L ^ 2)

para.p:
And we assert that the remainder term of the Taylor series is
⁢ O
(
∫
| w |
3
)
, because
R
is bounded. Therefore

Math.text: Delta * E = (open-interval@(L _ + * u, u)) _ (L ^ 2) + (open-interval@(L _ - * v, v)) _ (L ^ 2) + O * integral@((absolute-value@(w)) ^ 3)

para.p:
We can bound
∫
| w |
3
using the Gagliardo-Nirenberg inequality, which gives us (for
= n 3
)

for some
C 0
that doesn’t depend on
w
. Therefore

Math.text: Delta * E = (open-interval@(L _ + * u, u)) _ (L ^ 2) + (open-interval@(L _ - * v, v)) _ (L ^ 2) + O * ((norm@(w)) _ (H ^ 1)) ^ 3

para.p:
so there is some
C
such that

Math.text: Delta * E >= ((open-interval@(L _ + * u, u)) _ (L ^ 2) + (open-interval@(L _ - * v, v)) _ (L ^ 2)) - C * ((norm@(w)) _ (H ^ 1)) ^ 3
